snippet.title: The Gemini Planet Imager: First Light
snippet.description: The Gemini Planet Imager: First Light / Macintosh, Bruce (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory ; Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University) ; Graham, James R (University of California, Berkeley) ; Ingraham, Patrick (Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University) ; Konopacky, Quinn (University of Toronto) ; Marois, Christian (National Research Council of Canada) ; Perrin, Marshall (Space Telescope Science Institute) ; Poyneer, Lisa (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory) ; Bauman, Brian (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory) ; Barman, Travis (University of Arizona) ; Burrows, Adam (Princeton University) et al. The Gemini Planet Imager (GPI) is a dedicated facility for directly imaging and spectroscopically characterizing extrasolar planets. [...] arXiv:1403.7520. \- 2014\. - 9 p. Preprint

snippet.title: Ribbons characterize magnetohydrodynamic magnetic fields better than lines: a lesson from dynamo theory
snippet.description: Ribbons characterize magnetohydrodynamic magnetic fields better than lines: a lesson from dynamo theory / Blackman, Eric G (U. Rochester) ; Hubbard, Alex (American Museum of Natural History) Blackman & Brandenburg argued that magnetic helicity conservation in dynamo theory can in principle be captured by diagrams of mean field dynamos when the magnetic fields are represented by ribbons or tubes, but not by lines. [...] arXiv:1403.3445. \- 2014\. - 11 p. Preprint

snippet.title: Atomic jet from SMM1 (FIRS1) in Serpens uncovers non-coeval binary companion
snippet.description: Atomic jet from SMM1 (FIRS1) in Serpens uncovers non-coeval binary companion / Dionatos, O (University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, Austria ; Centre for Star and Planet Formation, Natural History Museum of Denmark, University of Copenhagen, Denmark ; Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark) ; Jørgensen, J K (Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark ; Centre for Star and Planet Formation, Natural History Museum of Denmark, University of Copenhagen, Denmark) ; Teixeira, P S (University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, Austria) ; Güdel, M (University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, Austria) ; Bergin, E (Department of Astronomy, University of Michigan, USA) We report on the detection of an atomic jet associated with the protostellar source SMM1 (FIRS1) in Serpens. [...] arXiv:1401.3249. \- 2014\. - 10 p. Preprint

snippet.title: Management of information organizations
snippet.description: Management of information organizations / Afzal, Waseem This book is a significant step towards developing a body of management knowledge pertinent to the context of Library Information Science (LIS) and provides a succinct but deep account of management and information organizations [...] Burlington, MA : Elsevier Science, 2012. - 181 p.

snippet.title: AGN and quasar science with aperture masking interferometry on the James Webb Space Telescope
snippet.description: AGN and quasar science with aperture masking interferometry on the James Webb Space Telescope / Ford, K E Saavik (Borough of Manhattan Community College, City University of New York ; American Museum of Natural History ; CUNY Graduate Center) ; McKernan, Barry (Borough of Manhattan Community College, City University of New York ; American Museum of Natural History ; CUNY Graduate Center) ; Sivaramakrishnan, Anand (Space Telescope Science Institute ; American Museum of Natural History ; SUNY Stony Brook) ; Martel, André R (Space Telescope Science Institute) ; Koekemoer, Anton (Space Telescope Science Institute) ; Lafrenière, David (Université de Montréal) ; Parmentier, Sébastien (SUNY Stony Brook) Due to feedback from accretion onto supermassive black holes (SMBHs), Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs) are believed to play a key role in LambdaCDM cosmology and galaxy formation. [...] arXiv:1401.0545. \- 2014\. - 18 p. Preprint

snippet.title: Digital images and art libraries in the twenty-first century
snippet.description: Digital images and art libraries in the twenty-first century / Wyngaard, Susan Increase your knowledge of the digital technology that is essential for art librarianship today! Digital Images and Art Libraries in the Twenty-First Century is your key to cutting-edge discourse on digital image databases and art libraries [...] Hoboken, NJ : Taylor and Francis, 2013. - 352 p.

snippet.title: The great Melbourne telescope
snippet.description: The great Melbourne telescope / Gillespie, Richard Erected at Melbourne Observatory in 1869, the telescope was the second largest in the world, designed to explore the nature of the nebulae in the southern skies. [...] Sydney : Museum Victoria, 2011. - 192 p.

snippet.title: PALM-3000: Exoplanet Adaptive Optics for the 5-meter Hale Telescope
snippet.description: PALM-3000: Exoplanet Adaptive Optics for the 5-meter Hale Telescope / Dekany, R ; Roberts, J ; Burruss, R ; Bouchez, A ; Truong, T ; Baranec, C ; Guiwits, S ; Hale, D ; Angione, J ; Trinh, T et al. We describe and report first results from PALM-3000, the second-generation astronomical adaptive optics facility for the 5.1-m Hale telescope at Palomar Observatory. [...] arXiv:1309.1216. \- 2013\. - 13 p. Preprint

snippet.title: Kepler-62: A five-planet system with planets of 1.4 and 1.6 Earth radii in the Habitable Zone
snippet.description: Kepler-62: A five-planet system with planets of 1.4 and 1.6 Earth radii in the Habitable Zone / Borucki, W J (NASA Ames Research Center) ; Agol, E (University of Washington) ; Fressin, F (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics) ; Kaltenegger, L (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics ; Max Planck Institute of Astronomy) ; Rowe, J (SETI Institute) ; Isaacson, H (University of California, Berkeley) ; Fischer, D (Yale University) ; Batalha, N (NASA Ames Research Center) ; Lissauer, J J (NASA Ames Research Center) ; Marcy, G W (University of California, Berkeley) et al. We present the detection of five planets -- Kepler-62b, c, d, e, and f -- of size 1.31, 0.54, 1.95, 1.61 and 1.41 Earth radii, orbiting a K2V star at periods of 5.7, 12.4, 18.2, 122.4 and 267.3 days, respectively. The outermost planets (Kepler-62e & -62f) are super-Earth-size (1.25 < planet radius/earth radius < 2.0) planets in the habitable zone (HZ) of their host star, receiving 1.2 +- 0.2 and 0.41 +- 0.05 times the solar flux at Earth's orbit. [...] arXiv:1304.7387.- 2013 \- Published in : Science Express / http://www.sciencemag.org/content/early/recent / 18 April 2013 / Page 1/ 10.1126/science.1234702 External link: Preprint

snippet.title: Mass loading and knot formation in AGN jets by stellar winds
snippet.description: Mass loading and knot formation in AGN jets by stellar winds / Huarte-Espinosa, Martin (U. of Rochester, NY) ; Blackman, Eric G (U. of Rochester, NY) ; Hubbard, Alex (American Museum of Natural History) ; Frank, Adam (U. of Rochester, NY) Jets from active galaxies propagate from the central black hole out to the radio lobes on scales of hundreds of kiloparsecs. [...] arXiv:1301.7081. \- 2013\. Preprint
